opposingBeliefs: You need a degree to succeed
College is the best investment you can make
mainClaim: The financial return on investment for traditional 4-year college degrees has significantly declined for most majors
evidence: A 2024 Georgetown University study analyzing 30 years of earnings data found that 40% of college graduates would have earned more over their lifetime by entering skilled trades immediately after high school. The average student debt of $37,000 now takes 14-20 years to pay off, with interest adding $15,000-25,000 to the total cost. For humanities and social science majors, median lifetime earnings gains versus high school graduates dropped from $900,000 (1990s) to $400,000 (2024), while college costs increased 180% after inflation. Meanwhile, electricians, plumbers, and software developers without degrees often earn $70,000-$120,000 within 5 years, with zero debt.
supportingPoints: Student loan crisis: $1.7 trillion in outstanding debt affecting 45 million Americans
Skilled trades facing worker shortage, driving wages up 40% in past decade
Tech industry increasingly hiring based on portfolio/skills rather than degrees
Opportunity cost: 4 years of lost earnings plus tuition vs. immediate income
Many degrees lead to jobs that don't require college education
Online learning and certifications provide cheaper alternatives
limitations: Study focused on median outcomes; individual results vary widely. STEM degrees still show strong ROI. Doesn't account for non-financial benefits like critical thinking, network, personal growth. Geographic factors matter significantly.
counterCounterArguments: Even for lower-ROI majors, graduates report higher job satisfaction and career flexibility
College degree still required for many professional fields (medicine, law, engineering)
Network effects and social capital from college can be valuable long-term

sourceMetadata.title: The College Payoff: More Education Doesn't Always Mean More Earnings
sourceMetadata.institution: Georgetown University Center on Education and the Workforce
sourceMetadata.methodology: 30-year longitudinal analysis of earnings data across all degree types
